#Text=10. The Braided Man of Pyramid Mountain
#Text=The mountain before them was shaped like a cone and was so tall that its point was lost in the clouds .
#Text=Directly facing the place where Jim had stopped was an arched opening leading to a broad stairway .

#Text=The stairs were cut in the rock inside the mountain , and they were broad and not very steep , because they circled around like a cork-screw , and at the arched opening where the flight began the circle was quite big .
#Text=At the foot of the stairs was a sign reading :
#Text=WARNING .
#Text=These steps lead to the Land of the Gargoyles .
#Text=DANGER !
#Text=KEEP OUT .
#Text="

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=I wonder how Jim is ever going to draw the buggy up so many stairs ,  said Dorothy , gravely .

_	_	_	_

#Text= No trouble at all , " declared the horse , with a contemptuous neigh . "

_	_	_	_

#Text= Suppose the stairs get steeper ? " suggested Zeb , doubtfully .

column1: #Text=" Then you 'll have to boost the buggy-wheels , that 's all , " answered Jim .
#Text=" We 'll try it , anyway , " said the Wizard .
#Text=" It 's the only way to get out of the Valley of Voe . "
#Text=So they began to ascend the stairs , Dorothy and the Wizard first , Jim next , drawing the buggy , and then Zeb to watch that nothing happened to the harness .
#Text=The light was dim , and soon they mounted into total darkness , so that the Wizard was obliged to get out his lanterns to light the way .
#Text=But this enabled them to proceed steadily until they came to a landing where there was a rift in the side of the mountain that let in both light and air .
#Text=Looking through this opening they could see the Valley of Voe lying far below them , the cottages seeming like toy houses from that distance .
#Text=After resting a few moments they resumed their climb , and still the stairs were broad and low enough for Jim to draw the buggy easily after him .
#Text=The old horse panted a little , and had to stop often to get his breath .
#Text=At such times they were all glad to wait for him , for continually climbing up stairs is sure to make one 's legs ache .
#Text=They wound about , always going upward , for some time .
#Text=The lights from the lanterns dimly showed the way , but it was a gloomy journey , and they were pleased when a broad streak of light ahead assured them they were coming to a second landing .
#Text=Here one side of the mountain had a great hole in it , like the mouth of a cavern , and the stairs stopped at the near edge of the floor and commenced ascending again at the opposite edge .
#Text=The opening in the mountain was on the side opposite to the Valley of Voe , and our travellers looked out upon a strange scene .
#Text=Below them was a vast space , at the bottom of which was a black sea with rolling billows , through which little tongues of flame constantly shot up .
#Text=Just above them , and almost on a level with their platform , were banks of rolling clouds which constantly shifted position and changed color .
#Text=The blues and greys were very beautiful , and Dorothy noticed that on the cloud banks sat or reclined fleecy , shadowy forms of beautiful beings who must have been the Cloud Fairies .

#Text=Mortals who stand upon the earth and look up at the sky cannot often distinguish these forms , but our friends were now so near to the clouds that they observed the dainty fairies very clearly .
#Text=" Are they real ? " asked Zeb , in an awed voice .
#Text=" Of course , " replied Dorothy , softly .
#Text=" They are the Cloud Fairies . "
#Text=" They seem like open-work , " remarked the boy , gazing intently .
#Text=" If I should squeeze one , there would n't be anything left of it . "
#Text=In the open space between the clouds and the black , bubbling sea far beneath , could be seen an occasional strange bird winging its way swiftly through the air .
#Text=These birds were of enormous size , and reminded Zeb of the rocs he had read about in the Arabian Nights .
#Text=They had fierce eyes and sharp talons and beaks , and the children hoped none of them would venture into the cavern .
#Text=" Well , I declare ! " suddenly exclaimed the little Wizard .
#Text=" What in the world is this ? "
#Text=They turned around and found a man standing on the floor in the center of the cave , who bowed very politely when he saw he had attracted their attention .
#Text=He was a very old man , bent nearly double ; but the queerest thing about him was his white hair and beard .
#Text=These were so long that they reached to his feet , and both the hair and the beard were carefully plaited into many braids , and the end of each braid fastened with a bow of colored ribbon .
#Text=" Where did you come from ? " asked Dorothy , wonderingly .
#Text=" No place at all , " answered the man with the braids ;
#Text=" that is , not recently .

#Text=Once I lived on top the earth , but for many years I have had my factory in this spot -- half way up Pyramid Mountain .

_	_	_	_

#Text= Are we only half way up ? " enquired the boy , in a discouraged tone .

column1: #Text=" I believe so , my lad , " replied the braided man .
#Text=" But as I have never been in either direction , down or up , since I arrived , I cannot be positive whether it is exactly half way or not . "
